title: What is it really like being a 1st or 2nd grade teacher? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve taught both 1st and 2nd grade students, and what it’s “really like” ranges from energizing to exhausting, triumphant to discouraged, appreciated to criticized. You get the idea, right? Teaching at those particular levels has some advantages—most students tend to LOVE their teachers (as long as the teacher treats them with respect and kindness, anyway), most parents want to be involved (ditto previous comment), and you get to see incredible growth and development in academic and social areas. On the other hand, 1st and 2nd grade teachers tend to be the ones that identify learning problems that might not be evident at earlier ages; this can be difficult for parents to hear. In the past twenty years, I’ve seen an increase in serious behavior concerns among students at these grade levels, and many teachers/school districts aren’t completely prepared to provide the resources needed to help these students succeed. That’s a topic for a different answer, but needs to be mentioned because you can’t assume you won’t deal with serious behavioral/emotional issues at any grade level. If I had to give a one sentence answer, I’d say being a 1st or 2nd grade teacher was the hardest job I’ve ever loved!

I haven’t taught first or second grade, but I used to volunteer at the elementary school library. One day my daughter’s first grade teacher came in, and groaned when she realized that the librarian was gone. She told me she really needed to use the toilet but she wasn’t supposed to leave the class unless another teacher could take over. I assured her I could do the story time so she could leave. The children were actually well behaved for me, partially because she had them well trained and partially because I was used to reading stories to my own children. I kept asking the student’s opinions so they would stay involved. But it is really much harder than that, because there is curriculum you have to teach, with assignments and grading. You have children that want to show off and others that melt down sometimes. Then there is lots of non-educational administrative work/record keeping that has to be done. But basically you have to like children that age, be willing to follow what the school district tells you to do without disregarding your own wisdom, and be able to hold it when you really need to go to the restroom.
